Award.AwardTitle: Semiparametric Methods for Analysis of Complex Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the era of big data, complex data naturally arise in modern scientific applications. For example, the advance in computation and technology has enabled the routine collection of high-frequency functional data and high-resolution images. Scientists are facing daunting challenges from the data, including the massive scale, intricate dependence structures, and various shape constraints that are vital for scientific interpretability. This project will develop new flexible methods for shape-constrained regression and high-dimensional quantile regression to comprehensively depict the dependence between variables, with a focus on providing scalable implementation and theoretically guaranteed inference. These tools will address pressing statistical and computational challenges, leading to broad applications in medicine, neuroscience, cancer-related studies, and industrial settings. The project will also develop and distribute open-source software and provide research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

The project will develop novel semiparametric methods for high-dimensional quantile regression and shape-constrained regression. The PI will investigate a paradigm shift in high-dimensional regression from a joint, iterative scheme to a two-step, distributed scheme. This strategy allows the utilization of parallel computation and is coupled with proper uncertainty propagation to ensure statistical optimality and frequentist coverage of simultaneous confidence and credible bands. Several regimes using functional and image data will be considered, for example, mean regression, quantile regression, and variable selection. The project will also develop new methods for nonparametric regression under shape constraints, including local sparsity and stationary points of unknown functions. The project will enrich the statistical toolbox to cope with complex data by developing a suite of semiparametric methods that are theoretically sound and computationally efficient.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the realm of big data analytics, scalability and interpretability continue to be pressing challenges across a wide range of scientific fields. This project addresses these challenges by focusing on two fronts: developing scalable quantile regression methods to capture heterogeneity in high-frequency functional data, and advancing shape-constrained regression techniques to enhance scientific interpretability.

In this project, we have proposed new methods with theoretical guarantees. In particular, we have developed semiparametric methods tailored for high-dimensional quantile regression. Through a two-step, distributed scheme, we have enabled the use of parallel computation, which not only accelerates the computation but also ensures optimal estimation accuracy and facilitates statistical inference. In the pursuit of interpretability, we have developed methods for nonparametric regression and functional data analysis subject to interpretable shape constraints. These techniques improve our ability to detect local sparsity and stationary points of unknown nonparametric functions in intricate datasets.

The advancements brought about by this project have substantially enriched the statistical tools available to researchers, offering solutions that are both theoretically sound and computationally efficient. This project addresses critical needs in fields where understanding intricate data dependence with interpretability is essential--for instance, in medical research using mass spectrometry proteomics for pancreatic cancer studies, and in neuroscience using electroencephalography data for understanding human language processing.

The project has made contributions to the scientific community by releasing open-source software, thus widening the accessibility of these methods. It has also supported educational development by providing research opportunities for students at the undergraduate and doctoral levels, as well as by supplying teaching materials.
